description: The Titanium Trochanter Fixation Nail System (TFN) is a titanium alloy third-generation  internal fixation device for proximal femur fractures, primarily trochanteric (intertrochanteric and subtrochanteric) fractures. Third-generation  devices were developed to reduce implant-related  complications associated with fixation of trochanteric fractures –Two versions(26) -The standard TFN is used for stable and unstable trochanteric fractures, pertrochanteric fractures, intertrochanteric fractures, basal neck fractures, or any combination of these -In addition to any of the above types of fractures the long TFN is used for subtrochanteric fractures, pertrochanteric fractures associated with femoral shaft fracture, pathologic fractures of osteoporotic bone in both the trochanteric and diaphyseal regions, long subtrochanteric fractures, proximal or distal nonunions, malunions, or revisions –The TFN is designed to reduce cutout rates and the risk of femoral shaft fracture.(1) Design characteristics of the TFN include: -Helical blade, rather than a screw, inserted into the femoral head without drilling -An anatomic 6˚ valgus angle in the femoral shaft component

Several classification systems for trochanteric hip fractures have been proposed.(2,) The AO classification(2) with groups has been noted as the most reliable(3,4,5) –AO classification for trochanteric fractures -The AO designation for proximal femur fractures passing through the trochanteric area is 31-A.  This fracture type is defined by a line passing through the lesser trochanter. The groups are: -A1 – simple pertrochanteric (both trochanters) fracture – the fracture line starts anywhere on the greater trochanter and ends either above or below the lesser trochanter -A2 – multi-fragmentary  pertrochanteric fracture – the fracture line starts anywhere on the greater trochanter and runs toward the medial cortex -A3 – “true” intertrochanteric fracture – the fracture line passes between the two trochanters

General description of the surgical technique for implanting the TFN(1) –Following anesthesia, a closed reduction of the fracture is performed –Under fluoroscopic control, a guide pin is inserted into the tip of the greater trochanter from the proximal direction –A channel is then drilled into the femoral canal and the nail is inserted  –A second guide pin is then advanced into the femoral cortex and femoral head –The helical blade is then inserted into the femoral head using light mallet blows –The device is then locked into place –A drain is used for 24–48  hours after surgery
indications: The TFN is indicated for use in trochanteric fractures

Incidence/Prevalence –Each year over 3000,000 patients 65 years or older are hospitalized in the US for hip fracture(27) –Based on the aging population, > 6 million hip fractures per year worldwide are projected by 2050, with 70% occurring in Asia, Latin America, and Africa(7) –In the United States intertrochanteric fractures account for ~ 45% of proximal femur fractures; subtrochanteric fractures account for 5–10%.(8) Femoral neck (cervical) fractures account for the remaining 45%(8) -Similar rates of trochanteric (referring to both intertrochanteric and subtrochanteric) fractures are reported in Norway(9) (40%) and Taiwan(10) (52%) –The incidence of trochanteric fracture rises with age –The lifetime prevalence of trochanteric fractures is higher in females than males(27) –Trochanteric fractures are associated with higher cost of care, mortality, and morbidity compared to cervical fractures(6,25)

Treatment –Surgical intervention is the treatment of choice for trochanteric fracture -Internal fixation devices are intended to accomplish the following: -Anatomic reduction -Early, active mobilization -Stable fixation -Preservation of blood supply
The TFN can be used to treat stable and unstable trochanteric fractures

ICD-10 codes.S72.2: subtrochanteric fracture (ICD codes are provided for readers’ reference, not for billing purposes)

reimbursement: Reimbursement for therapy depends on insurance coverage; no specific issues regarding reimbursement have been identified as concerns in physical therapy for hip fractures Surgical Indications, Contraindications, & Complications
contraindications precautions to test: Specific guidelines regarding hip precautions or restrictions should be obtained from the referring surgeon
Reduced cognitive function, which can affect participation in examination and treatment, may be present

overall contraindications precautions: Examination and treatment should be postponed if any of the following is noted Fever above 102˚F/38.5˚C Wound infection  Deep vein thrombosis (DVT)
Obtain informed consent from the patient or legal caretaker
Precautions Presence of comorbid pathology Low HCT or Hgb

contraindications precautions to examina: Specific guidelines regarding hip precautions or restrictions should be obtained from the referring surgeon
Reduced cognitive function, which can affect participation in examination and treatment, may be present

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: Trochanteric fractures in older adults are associated with falls (low-energy trauma) and osteoporosis. Fractures in younger persons are generally caused by high-energy  trauma (motor vehicle accidents, falls from more than standing height) -More than 95% of hip fractures are caused by falls(27)

course of treatment.medical management: Note surgical course  uneventful, preoperative or postoperative complications. Document DVT prophylaxis/management, if any
course of treatment.medications: Determine what medications clinician has prescribed; are they being taken? Medication may include postoperative analgesics, anticoagulants, and antibiotics
diagnostic tests completed: Diagnostic tests completed:  Usual tests for this condition are the following:
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies (e.g., ice or heating pack) or alternative therapies (e.g., acupuncture) and whether they help
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether the patient has had occupational or physical therapy for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Document factors that aggravate or relieve symptoms and length of time each item is performed before the symptoms come on or are eased
history of present illness.body chart: Use body chart to document location and nature of symptoms
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Document nature of symptoms. Expect limited ROM, pain, weakness, difficulty with walking and ADLs
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale (V AS) or 010  scale to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, and currently(specifically address if pain is present now and how much)
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (a.m., mid-day,  p.m., night); document changes in symptoms due to weather or other external variables
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms the patient may be experiencing that could exacerbate the condition and/ or symptoms that could be indicative of a need to refer to physician (e.g., dizziness, bowel/bladder/sexual dysfunction, saddle anesthesia)
history of present illness.respiratory status: Note use of oxygen, presence of respiratory diseaseNote signs of depression and social isolation (due to loss of ambulatory status)Note signs of hearing impairment Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes__ No__ -If Yes, describe ________________________

past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Note previous hip pathology and treatment. Fall history, if any, should be documented
past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Ask the patient about other problems, including osteoporosis, diabetes, cancer, heart disease, Parkinson disease, psychiatric disorders, and orthopedic disorders
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including OTC drugs)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask the patient about other symptoms he or she may be experiencing, including related musculoskeletal complaints

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: Does the patient participate in recreational or competitive sports? Is the patient currently employed or planning to return to work?
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: Any limitations with self-care,  home management, work, community leisure etc. prior to TFN? Any additional limitations since TFN? Note use of assistive devices prior to injury
social and occupational history.living environment: Stairs, number of floors in home, with whom the patient lives, caregivers, etc. Identify if there are barriers to independence in the home; any modifications necessary?

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be ›Relevant tests and measures: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting)
relevant tests and measures.anthropometric characteristics: Measure leg length to document any discrepancy. Assess BMI, height, weight
relevant tests and measures.assistive and adaptive devices: Assess need, appropriateness, and fit for assistive devices for ambulation (walker, cane, wheelchair, crutches). Assess for need of adaptive devices in the home (shower chair, grab bars, reachers)
relevant tests and measures.balance: Assess dynamic (walking, walking on toes) and static (single-leg  stance, if appropriate) balance. Possible tests include the Berg Balance Scale(15) and Tinetti Balance Assessment(16)
relevant tests and measures.circulation: Assess peripheral pulsesAssess gait speed. Gait speed is predictive of outcomes. One of its extensive predictive capabilities is risk for falls(28)
relevant tests and measures.functional mobility: Assess transfers, sitting down and getting up, bending, turning, etc. Weight-bearing  restrictions and hip precautions, if any, should be observed. Functional mobility may be assessed with the Timed Up and Go (TUG) test.(17,18) The Functional Independence Measure (FIM)(19) may be used for a more comprehensive assessment
relevant tests and measures.gait locomotion: Assess walking ability. Note presence of Trendelenburg gait, indicating hip abductor weakness. Assess for gait deviations such as step length,increased step width, limited foot clearance, decreased hip extension, and changes in posture with gaitShort-Form  Health Survey (SF-36  or SF-12)Assess for motion restrictions in the hip and related joints. Observe hip precautions, if any
relevant tests and measures.muscle strength: Assess muscle strength in the leg with MMT and/or functional strength measures
observation inspection palpation includi: Note presence of edema and/or hematoma
Patients with reduced mobility are at risk for decubiti assess for skin breakdown •Palpation:  Palpate for tender points in muscle and other structures
relevant tests and measures.range of motion: Assess ROM of hip, knee, ankle, and lumbar spine. Observe hip precautions, if any
relevant tests and measures.arousal attention cognition: Assess orientation x4. Cognitive decline related to aging should be documented. Possible measures include Mini-Mental  State Examination (MMSE)(14)

cryotherapy contraindications: Cryotherapy  contraindications -Cold urticaria -Cold intolerance -Paroxysmal cold hemoglobinuria -Cryoglobulinemia -Raynaud’s disease or phenomenon -Over a regenerating peripheral nerve -Over a circulatory compromise -Over an area of peripheral vascular disease

Precautions for cryotherapy  (20) -Hypertension -Thermoregulatory disorders -Over a superficial peripheral nerve -Over an open wound -Over an area of poor sensation -With individuals with poor cognition -In the very young and the very old -Persons with an aversion to cold

Superficial heat  contraindications(20) -Over areas with a lack of intact thermal sensation -Over areas of vascular insufficiency or vascular disease -Over areas of recent hemorrhage or potential hemorrhage -Over areas of known malignancy -Over areas of acute inflammation -Over infected areas where infection may spread -Over areas where liniments or heat rubs have recently been applied -In any situation deemed unreliable by the practitioner

Electrotherapy  contraindications(20) (in rare cases, and only when approved by the treating physician , electrotherapy may be used under some of the conditions listed below if the potential benefit outweighs the perceived risk) -Over the trunk or heart region in patients with demand-type  pacemakers and implantable cardioverter defibrillators (ICDs) -Over the pelvic, abdominal, lumbar, or hip region of a pregnant woman -Over the carotid bodies -Over the phrenic nerve, eyes, or gonads -Over areas of known peripheral vascular disease -Over areas of active osteomyelitis -Over areas of hemorrhage

Electrotherapy precautions(20) -With patients without intact sensation -With patients who cannot communicate -With patients with compromised mental ability -With cardiac dysfunction (uncontrolled hypertension or hypotension, irregular heartbeat) -Overactive or previous neoplasms -With electrodes -Over compromised skin, unless treating wound specifically -Over tissues that are vulnerable to hemorrhage  -Cervical region in patients with history of stroke or seizures -Do not use within 5 yards of diathermy units or other source of electromagnetic radiation

Ultrasound, continuous Contraindications(20) -During pregnancy, over the abdomen and low back -Overactive bone growth at the epiphysis -Over a known or suspected area for cancer -Over the infected tissue in a tuberculosis infection
-Over an area of active bleeding  can be used in area of hematoma

-Over skin with impaired circulation  recommend using pulsed -Following are considered contraindications but have no evidence to support -Myositis ossificans -DVT or thrombophlebitis -Acute injury -Recently irradiated tissue -Impaired sensation due to nerve damage -Skin disease -Implanted cardiac pacemaker or other implanted electronics -Reproductive organs -Eyes -Anterior neck -Metal implants, head, and heart often listed but consensus is these should not be contraindications
-Ultrasound, continuous Precautions(20) -Over plastic or cemented implants -Over spinal cord and superficial or regenerating nerves (poor evidence)

-Ultrasound, pulsed Contraindications(20) -Over low back and abdomen during pregnancy -Over known or suspected area of malignancy -Over area of active bleeding -Following are considered contraindications but have no evidence to support -Myositis ossificans -DVT or thrombophlebitis -Recently irradiated tissue -Implanted cardiac pacemaker or other implanted electronics -Reproductive organs -Eyes -Anterior neck

-Ultrasound, pulsed Precautions(20) -Over epiphysis with active bone growth -Over infected area -Over acute injury -Over area of impaired sensation due to nerve damage -With patients with impaired cognition or communication -Over areas of impaired circulation -In the presence of skin disease -Over plastic and cemented implants -Over spinal cord and superficial or regenerating nerves (poor evidence)

Low-level  laser therapy (LLLT)  contraindications(20) -Direct eye exposure -Pregnancy (low back and pelvic area) -Active malignancy (over area) -Active hemorrhage (over area)  -Open growth plates -Endocrine system (especially thyroid in anterior neck)

Aquatic therapy  contraindications(20) -Bowel or bladder incontinence -Tracheostomy -Infectious diseases -Cardiovascular problems -Uncontrolled seizures -Respiratory compromise with vital capacity less than 1 liter
Aquatic therapy  precautions(20) -Aspiration risk -Catheters -Cognitive impairments -Tetraplegia or high paraplegia -Open wounds -Dry skin or skin rashes or rash
other: Patients with a diagnosis for which this procedure is used are at risk for falls; follow facility protocols for fall prevention and post fall-prevention  instructions at bedside if inpatient. Ensure that patient and family/caregivers  are aware of the potential for falls and educated about fall-prevention strategies. Discharge criteria should include independence with fall-prevention  strategies
Observe restrictions or rehabilitation parameters prescribed by physician

Clinicians should follow the guidelines of their clinic/hospital and what is ordered by the patient’s physician. The summary below is meant to serve as a guide, not to replace orders from a physician or a clinic’s specific protocols

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: Diagnosis/need for procedure Trochanteric fracture with associated problems of decreased functional mobility, ability to ambulate, strength, balance, and ROM
prognosis: Some functional loss may occur after a fall resulting in hip fracture with subsequent surgical fixation(21) –Based on a retrospective review of 660 patients in Spain -Functional loss (compared to pre-fracture  condition) in walking, navigating stairs, performing transfers, dressing, and bathing persisted in 25–35%  of patients after 2 years -Functional recovery of non-weight-bearing  ADLs compared to weight bearing ADLs was greater, but difficulty with bowel and bladder control and feeding was noted in 10–15%  of patients

Researchers of a study from Austria recommend a total hip arthroplasty as the only salvage method for complications that result from a cut-out  and cut-through  with helical blades for individuals treated with a TFN or Proximal Femoral Nail Anti-rotation  (PFNA)(24)

Hip fractures are associated with increased mortality. Within the first year of fracture, 20-30%  die. Those that survive may not re-gain  their pre-fracture  level of function with about 50% requiring assistance to ambulate and about 25% requiring long-term care(29)
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Occupational therapy for assistance with ADLs, pain management specialist, geriatrician for management of comorbid conditions, eye doctor (if vision is impaired), social work for home needs, psychologist for cognitive issues
treatment summary: Rehabilitation following fixation of trochanteric fractures with the TFN includes early mobilization and immediate or early weight-bearing(22) –Based on a clinical review of 120 patients treated with the TFN in Germany -93% of patients were mobilized, including sitting, on the first postoperative day -74% were able to walk with crutches or assistance of another person after 1 week -7% were unable to get out of bed during the hospital stay (average 17 days)

Rehabilitation after fixation of subtrochanteric fracture using the long TFN includes immediate weight-bearing(13) –Based on a clinical review of 21 patients in Spain -Postoperative management included sitting within 1 day and weight-bearing  within 48 hours, according to patient tolerance -62% of patients were able to walk within the first week  -Weight-bearing  status and independence level were not reported
Functional training (postural, gait, balance, fall prevention) and strength training are appropriate physical therapy interventions following TFN surgery

For review of physical therapy interventions following proximal hip fracture, please see  Clinical Review…Fracture, Hip ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T708879 . improved gait, posture, and balance, imp: Gait assessment–Gait speed–Step length and width–2-minute  walk test–6-minute  walk test

maintenance or prevention: Fall prevention program, including home modifications
Physical fitness program, including balance training
patient education: Information on hip fractures is available at https://www.cdc.gov/HomeandRecreationalSafety/Falls/adulthipfx.html Note
